elements.content: Pyrazine- N,N ′-dioxide (pzdo) was used as a linker in the design and synthesis of hybrid octacyanometalate-based networks. Four new compounds Na6[WV(CN)8]2(pzdo)7·5H2O (1), K3[WV(CN)8](pzdo)2·4H2O (2), {MnII 6(pzdo)4(MeOH)10[WV(CN)8]4}·4MeOH (3), and {MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[WIV(CN)8]}·4H2O (4) reveal specific M-pzdo-[W(CN)8]3–/4– (M = NaI, KI, MnII) structural arrangements where pzdo plays a significant role. Apart from typical supramolecular interactions including hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions, the {[M(μ-pzdo)M][W(CN)8] x } (x = 1 or 2) structural motifs in 1–4 are organized by specific supramolecular interactions of the pzdo molecule and the octacyanotungstate anions: face-to-face sandwich type interactions between the plane of the pzdo aromatic ring and N4 square face of [W(CN)8] n− anions, edge-to-face interactions between the plane of the pyrazine ring and a pair of neighboring NCN atoms of the [W(CN)8]-moiety, and end-to-face interactions between the plane of the pyrazine ring and a single NCN atoms of the [W(CN)8]-moiety. The related intermolecular arrangements show features typical for anion−π interactions, unprecedented in the octacyanometalate chemistry. The specific interactions of the octacyanotungstate and the pzdo molecule in 1 and 2 lead to significant modification of their electronic spectra. Magnetic studies revealed that 1, 2, and 4 are paramagnetic, although 3 orders antiferromagnetically at T c = 17.5 K.

elements.content:
Specific π(pzdo)−[W(CN)8] n− supramolecular interactions control the crystal structure, optical, and magnetic properties of hybrid organic−inorganic networks with M n+−pzdo−[W(CN)8] n− linkages

Introduction

Inorganic–organic octacyanometalate-based molecular materials, exhibiting magneto-optical effects, magnetic sponges, local and bulk magnetic anisotropy, chirality and magnetic ordering or thermally and optically induced spin transitions, have attracted intense attention. The construction of cyanido-bridged frameworks by the building blocks approach with the [M(CN)8] n− and 3d- or 4f-complexes exhibiting targeted chemical and physical properties is definitely assisted by bridging, blocking, or chelating organic molecules with different size and structure ().
elements.clean_text:
Specific π(pzdo)-[W(CN)8] n- supramolecular interactions control the crystal structure, optical, and magnetic properties of hybrid organic-inorganic networks with M n+-pzdo-[W(CN)8] n- linkages

Introduction

Inorganic-organic octacyanometalate-based molecular materials, exhibiting magneto-optical effects, magnetic sponges, local and bulk magnetic anisotropy, chirality and magnetic ordering or thermally and optically induced spin transitions, have attracted intense attention. The construction of cyanido-bridged frameworks by the building blocks approach with the [M(CN)8] n- and 3d- or 4f-complexes exhibiting targeted chemical and physical properties is definitely assisted by bridging, blocking, or chelating organic molecules with different size and structure ().

elements.content: In our pursuit of novel [M(CN)8]-bridged coordination polymers with magnetic ordering and magnetic anisotropy, we have employed the azine N-oxides family as ligands offering a rich bonding ability, where supramolecular interactions (hydrogen bonds, π–π interactions) strongly cooperate or compete with coordination bonds: chelating modes, end-to-end bridging and end-on bridging. The pzdo-bridged (pzdo = pyrazine- N,N ′-dioxide) coordination systems are represented by assemblies of general composition {M–L–A} (M = Mn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ln3+; L = pzdo and derivatives; A m– = Br–, Cl–, ClO4 –, SCN–, N3 –, [W(CN)8]3–), some of them combining hybrid character with interesting magnetic features. Remarkably, the ability of pzdo to create anion−π interactions is very poorly recognized in pzdo-based systems, in spite of the proper mutual orientation between anions and pzdo that could be observed. The anion−π interaction is a relatively new type of supramolecular interaction, which has been recognized only during the past decade and has been described for electron deficient π systems. Such systems could be obtained by the protonation/alkyl-substitution of N heteroatoms toward ArN⊕-H/ArN⊕-R cationic species, respectively, or by the functionalization of C atoms with electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., −F, −CN). The π-acidity of pzdo could be reasonably inferred from a significant electronic charge polarization in Oδ‑Nδ+ group, which should create the positive electrostatic potential of π system.

The pzdo-bridged (pzdo = pyrazine- N,N '-dioxide) coordination systems are represented by assemblies of general composition {M-L-A} (M = Mn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ln3+; L = pzdo and derivatives; A m- = Br-, Cl-, ClO4 -, SCN-, N3 -, [W(CN)8]3-), some of them combining hybrid character with interesting magnetic features. Remarkably, the ability of pzdo to create anion-π interactions is very poorly recognized in pzdo-based systems, in spite of the proper mutual orientation between anions and pzdo that could be observed. The anion-π interaction is a relatively new type of supramolecular interaction, which has been recognized only during the past decade and has been described for electron deficient π systems. Such systems could be obtained by the protonation/alkyl-substitution of N heteroatoms toward ArN⊕-H/ArN⊕-R cationic species, respectively, or by the functionalization of C atoms with electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., -F, -CN). The π-acidity of pzdo could be reasonably inferred from a significant electronic charge polarization in Oδ-Nδ+ group, which should create the positive electrostatic potential of π system.

elements.content: As part of our effort in this direction, herein we describe the novel group of hybrid networks built of {M(μ-pzdo)M[W(CN)8] x } (M = Na+, K+, Mn2+; x = 1 or 2) structural motifs, accompanied by anion−π interactions between the octacyanometalate anions and the pzdo aromatic rings. The first two presented compounds, paramagnetic Na6(pzdo)7[W(CN)8]2·5H2O (1) and K 3(pzdo)2[WV(CN)8]·4H2O (2), reveal a significant modification of their electronic absorption spectra in solution and in solid state, compared to the traditional Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O and K3[W(CN)8]·1.5H2O salts. Incorporation of MnII ions in different synthetic conditions leads to the layered 2D magnet {Mn6(pzdo)4(MeOH)10[W(CN)8]4}·4MeOH (3) with T c = 17.5 K or to paramagnetic 3D network {MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[WIV(CN)8]}·4H2O (4).

The first two presented compounds, paramagnetic Na6(pzdo)7[W(CN)8]2⋅5H2O (1) and K 3(pzdo)2[WV(CN)8]⋅4H2O (2), reveal a significant modification of their electronic absorption spectra in solution and in solid state, compared to the traditional Na3[W(CN)8]⋅4H2O and K3[W(CN)8]⋅1.5H2O salts. Incorporation of MnII ions in different synthetic conditions leads to the layered 2D magnet {Mn6(pzdo)4(MeOH)10[W(CN)8]4}⋅4MeOH (3) with T c = 17.5 K or to paramagnetic 3D network {MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[WIV(CN)8]}⋅4H2O (4).

elements.content: Pyrazine was purchased from a commercial source (Aldrich) and used as obtained. Pyrazine-N,N′-dioxide (pzdo) was synthesized according to the literature methods. Potassium octacyanotungstate(IV) dihydrate K4[W(CN)8]·2H2O and sodium octacyanotungstate(V) tetrahydrate Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O were prepared according to the literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Pyrazine was purchased from a commercial source (Aldrich) and used as obtained. Pyrazine-N,N'-dioxide (pzdo) was synthesized according to the literature methods. Potassium octacyanotungstate(IV) dihydrate K4[W(CN)8]⋅2H2O and sodium octacyanotungstate(V) tetrahydrate Na3[W(CN)8]⋅4H2O were prepared according to the literature procedures.

elements.content: Aqueous solutions of pzdo (112.1 mg, 1.0 mmol, 2 mL) and Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O (266.5 mg, 0.5 mmol, 2 mL) were mixed. The resulting brown solution was filtered and left for slow evaporation in the dark. After 2 weeks, brown crystals appeared. The crystals were recovered by filtration, washed with a small amount of cold water (4 °C), and air-dried. Yield: 137 mg, 53%. Anal. Calcd for C44H38N30Na6O19W2: C, 29.4; H, 2.1; N, 23.4. Found: C, 29.3; H, 2.0; N, 23.3. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3597m, 3489s, 3437s, 3380m(br,sh), 3137s, 3082s, 3065s, 3040m, 2148m, 1640m, 1631m(sh), 1477s, 1461s, 1450s, 1309m, 1292m, 1261vs, 1232s(sh), 1173m, 1080w, 1055s, 946w, 860s, 810vs, 686w, 578w(br), 535m, 500w, 444m, 419s.

elements.content: A MeOH suspension of pzdo (0.27 mmol, 0.0302 g, 10 mL) was mixed with MeOH solution containing MnCl2·4H2O (0.054 mmol, 0.0107 g, 10 mL) and Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O (0.036 mmol, 0.0192 g). The mixture was tightly closed in a conical flask and kept in water bath at 40 °C. After 1 week, the flask was slightly unsealed, which allowed a slow exchange of solvent vapors. After 2 days, elongated, needle-shaped, brown crystals of 3 appeared. The crystals together with a small portion of mother solution were separated mechanically from the pzdo suspension and characterized by monocrystalline X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurement. The fast degradation of crystallinity of 3 was observed after their removal from the mother liquor due to the exchange of MeOH to H2O. This yield in the dark brown material of empirical formula {Mn6(pzdo)4[W(CN)8]4}·3MeOH·8H2O (see elemental analysis below). Yield: 4 mg ca. 8%. Anal. Calcd for C51H44Mn6N40O19W4: C, 23.6; H, 2.0; N, 21.6. Found: C, 23.8; H, 2.2; N, 21.6. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3478v, 3363, 3216, 3023, 2916, 2847, 2174m, 2150m, 2132w, 1623m, 1602s, 1477s, 1451s, 1314m, 1251m, 1236m, 1184vw, 1082w, 1053s, 878m, 848m, 811vs, 600w, 466m.

After 2 days, elongated, needle-shaped, brown crystals of 3 appeared. The crystals together with a small portion of mother solution were separated mechanically from the pzdo suspension and characterized by monocrystalline X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurement. The fast degradation of crystallinity of 3 was observed after their removal from the mother liquor due to the exchange of MeOH to H2O. This yield in the dark brown material of empirical formula {Mn6(pzdo)4[W(CN)8]4}⋅3MeOH⋅8H2O (see elemental analysis below). Yield: 4 mg ca. 8%. Anal. elements.content: Aqueous solutions of MnCl2·4H2O (0.5 mmol, 99 mg, 1 mL) and pzdo (5 mmol, 112 mg, 5 mL) were mixed, and then an aqueous solution of Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O (0.5 mmol, 266 mg, 5 mL) was added. The resulting red solution was filtered. After a few days, thin orange needles were obtained, separated by filtration, and removed. The supernatant was left in the dark. After 3 weeks, red prismatic single crystals suitable for structure determination were obtained. Yield: 15.2 mg, ca. 8%. Anal. Calcd for C12H20Mn2N10O10W: C, 19.0; H, 2.7; N, 18.5. Found: C, 19.3; H, 2.5; N, 18.7. IR (in KBr, cm–1): 3592m, 3445s(br), 2960vw, 2925w, 2851vw, 2169w(sh), 2148m(sh), 2132s, 2124s, 1621s, 1597s, 1477m, 1454s, 1311vw, 1294w, 1248m, 1233m, 1186w, 1084w, 1056m, 850m, 807s, 540vw, 480vw, 452w, 421vw.

{MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[WIV(CN)8]}⋅4H2O (4)

Aqueous solutions of MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.5 mmol, 99 mg, 1 mL) and pzdo (5 mmol, 112 mg, 5 mL) were mixed, and then an aqueous solution of Na3[W(CN)8]⋅4H2O (0.5 mmol, 266 mg, 5 mL) was added. The resulting red solution was filtered. After a few days, thin orange needles were obtained, separated by filtration, and removed. The supernatant was left in the dark. After 3 weeks, red prismatic single crystals suitable for structure determination were obtained. Yield: 15.2 mg, ca. 8%. Anal. Calcd for C12H20Mn2N10O10W: C, 19.0; H, 2.7; N, 18.5. Found: C, 19.3; H, 2.5; N, 18.7. IR (in KBr, cm-1): 3592m, 3445s(br), 2960vw, 2925w, 2851vw, 2169w(sh), 2148m(sh), 2132s, 2124s, 1621s, 1597s, 1477m, 1454s, 1311vw, 1294w, 1248m, 1233m, 1186w, 1084w, 1056m, 850m, 807s, 540vw, 480vw, 452w, 421vw.

elements.content: Diffraction data were collected at T = 293 K (1, 3, 4), or at T = 100 K (2) using the Nonius-Bruker KappaCCD four circle diffractometer, equipped with the Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) radiation source, graphite monochromator, and Oxford Cryostream system for measurements at low temperature. For the measurement of 3, the crystal was held in the sealed capillary. For the crystal structure of 1 and 2, cell refinements and data reduction were performed using DENZO and HKL SCALEPACK programs. The structure solution was executed using SIR-97, whereas the refinement procedure and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97 program with the WinGX graphical user interface. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All H atoms connected to aromatic C atoms of the organic component were positioned in an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.2Ueq(C). H atoms of water molecules forming close contacts with alkali metals were found from the difference Fourier map. It was impossible to determine the positions of two H atoms of water molecule in 1. For the crystal structure of 3 and 4, the space groups were determined using the ABSEN61 program. The crystal structures were solved by the Patterson method using the program SHELXS-97. The refinement and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97 with the WinGX graphical user interface. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon atoms in organic components were positioned with idealized geometry and refined using a riding model, with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.2 Ueq(C). H atoms in water molecules in 4 were found from the difference Fourier map, and then refined using a riding model with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.5 Ueq(O). Some restraints on the bond lengths (CO), and thermal ellipsoids of C atoms of solvent and coordinated methanol molecules in 3 were used in order to maintain the proper geometry and to ensure the convergence of the refinement process. The selected crystallographic data for the studied compounds are shown in Table . Structural artworks were prepared using Mercury 1.4.1 program.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Solution and Refinement

Diffraction data were collected at T = 293 K (1, 3, 4), or at T = 100 K (2) using the Nonius-Bruker KappaCCD four circle diffractometer, equipped with the Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) radiation source, graphite monochromator, and Oxford Cryostream system for measurements at low temperature. For the measurement of 3, the crystal was held in the sealed capillary. For the crystal structure of 1 and 2, cell refinements and data reduction were performed using DENZO and HKL SCALEPACK programs. The structure solution was executed using SIR-97, whereas the refinement procedure and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97 program with the WinGX graphical user interface. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All H atoms connected to aromatic C atoms of the organic component were positioned in an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.2Ueq(C). H atoms of water molecules forming close contacts with alkali metals were found from the difference Fourier map. It was impossible to determine the positions of two H atoms of water molecule in 1. For the crystal structure of 3 and 4, the space groups were determined using the ABSEN61 program. The crystal structures were solved by the Patterson method using the program SHELXS-97. The refinement and further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97 with the WinGX graphical user interface. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon atoms in organic components were positioned with idealized geometry and refined using a riding model, with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.2 Ueq(C). H atoms in water molecules in 4 were found from the difference Fourier map, and then refined using a riding model with Uiso(H) fixed at 1.5 Ueq(O). Some restraints on the bond lengths (CO), and thermal ellipsoids of C atoms of solvent and coordinated methanol molecules in 3 were used in order to maintain the proper geometry and to ensure the convergence of the refinement process. The selected crystallographic data for the studied compounds are shown in Table . Structural artworks were prepared using Mercury 1.4.1 program.

Infrared spectra were measured in KBr pellets in the range between 4000 and 400 cm–1 using a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a EuroEA EuroVector elemental analyzer. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL magnetometer and a Quantum Design MPMS-3 EVERCOOL magnetometer. Solid state UV–vis–NIR reflectance spectra were carried out with PerkinElmer Lambda 30 spectrophotometer equipped with a 50 mm integrating sphere. The geometry of coordination polyhedra has been established by continuous shape measures (CSM) analysis, following the ideas of Alvarez and co-workers.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Techniques and Computational Methods

Infrared spectra were measured in KBr pellets in the range between 4000 and 400 cm-1 using a Bruker EQUINOX 55 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a EuroEA EuroVector elemental analyzer. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL magnetometer and a Quantum Design MPMS-3 EVERCOOL magnetometer. Solid state UV-vis-NIR reflectance spectra were carried out with PerkinElmer Lambda 30 spectrophotometer equipped with a 50 mm integrating sphere. The geometry of coordination polyhedra has been established by continuous shape measures (CSM) analysis, following the ideas of Alvarez and co-workers.

elements.content: The compounds 1 and 2 are very well soluble in aqueous media, and their crystallization required relatively high concentrations (ca. 0.25–0.5 M) of the reactants. The average crystallization time for a reasonable amount of products was ca. 2 weeks. Both compounds showed a tendency to produce a few crystals per batch achieving rather large size after longer time of crystallization: long and thick rectangular prims (up to ca. 10 × 2 × 2 mm2) for 1 and thick bars with visibly truncated vertices and edges (up to ca. 10 × 8 × 2 mm2) for 2. A very small yield reported for 3 and 4 is due to the fact that their crystallization proceeded only as a result of a slow appearance of additional indispensable components: atmospheric water solubilizing pzdo in the case of 3 or reduced [W(CN)8]4– anion in the case of 4. We did not note the reasonable increase in yields after the longer crystallization time. The orange needles preceding the growth of 4 were few and too small for monocrystalline XRD measurement, thus we did not examine it.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and IR Spectroscopy

The compounds 1 and 2 are very well soluble in aqueous media, and their crystallization required relatively high concentrations (ca. 0.25-0.5 M) of the reactants. The average crystallization time for a reasonable amount of products was ca. 2 weeks. Both compounds showed a tendency to produce a few crystals per batch achieving rather large size after longer time of crystallization: long and thick rectangular prims (up to ca. 10 × 2 × 2 mm2) for 1 and thick bars with visibly truncated vertices and edges (up to ca. 10 × 8 × 2 mm2) for 2. A very small yield reported for 3 and 4 is due to the fact that their crystallization proceeded only as a result of a slow appearance of additional indispensable components: atmospheric water solubilizing pzdo in the case of 3 or reduced [W(CN)8]4- anion in the case of 4. We did not note the reasonable increase in yields after the longer crystallization time. The orange needles preceding the growth of 4 were few and too small for monocrystalline XRD measurement, thus we did not examine it.

elements.content: The different coordination modes of pzdo and CN– ligands along the series 1–4 were examined by IR spectroscopy and the results were compared to the IR spectra of octacyanidometalate salts, pzdo, and the literature hybrid cyanide-bridged and pzdo-bridged compound {MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[NbIV(CN)8]}·4H2O (5). collects the most indicative features in selected ranges of the v(CN) (2200–2100 cm–1), v(N–O) (1320–1220 cm–1), CC and CN ring deformation (1500–1450 cm–1), and in-plane and out of plane C–H (1300–1170 cm–1, 1100–1000 cm–1 and 900–800 cm–1) vibrations. In the range of stretching CN vibrations, 1 and 2 show the strong narrow bands at 2148 and 2139 cm–1, respectively, in agreement with the absence of classical coordination of [W(CN)8]3– to 3d metal ions. The residue of 3 shows the bands at 2174m, 2150m, and 2132w, whereas 4 shows the bands at 2169w(sh), 2148m(sh), 2132s, 2124s. This is in agreement with the coexistence of bridging and terminal CN– ligands of [W(CN)8]3– in 3 and of [W(CN)8]4– in 4. In the range of pzdo vibrations the most distinct differences between the spectra of pzdo and 1–4 occurs in the following regions: 1460–1430 cm–1 (↑ up 15 cm–1 for 1–4), 1265–1230 cm–1 (↓ up to 25 cm–1 for 3 and 4), 1060–1020 cm–1 (↑ up to 25 cm–1 for 1–4), 880–840 cm–1 (↓ up to 20 cm–1 for 1–4), and 820–800 cm–1 (↑ up to 10 cm–1 for 1–4) (↓ and ↑ indicate the increase and the decrease of peak maximum wavenumber, respectively, of ca. 10–25 cm–1). The observed tendency is also in a perfect agreement with the IR data reported previously for 5 and could be generally assigned to the bridging coordination and significant change of structural environment and intermolecular interaction in 1–5.

In the range of stretching CN vibrations, 1 and 2 show the strong narrow bands at 2148 and 2139 cm-1, respectively, in agreement with the absence of classical coordination of [W(CN)8]3- to 3d metal ions. The residue of 3 shows the bands at 2174m, 2150m, and 2132w, whereas 4 shows the bands at 2169w(sh), 2148m(sh), 2132s, 2124s. This is in agreement with the coexistence of bridging and terminal CN- ligands of [W(CN)8]3- in 3 and of [W(CN)8]4- in 4. In the range of pzdo vibrations the most distinct differences between the spectra of pzdo and 1-4 occurs in the following regions: 1460-1430 cm-1 (↑ up 15 cm-1 for 1-4), 1265-1230 cm-1 (↓ up to 25 cm-1 for 3 and 4), 1060-1020 cm-1 (↑ up to 25 cm-1 for 1-4), 880-840 cm-1 (↓ up to 20 cm-1 for 1-4), and 820-800 cm-1 (↑ up to 10 cm-1 for 1-4) (↓ and ↑ indicate the increase and the decrease of peak maximum wavenumber, respectively, of ca. 10-25 cm-1). The observed tendency is also in a perfect agreement with the IR data reported previously for 5  and could be generally assigned to the bridging coordination and significant change of structural environment and intermolecular interaction in 1-5.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 is presented in Figure and . The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . The asymmetric unit is composed of 3 Na+ cations, 1 [W(CN)8]3– anion, 3.5 pzdo molecules and 2.5 H2O molecules (the O41N41­C42C43­C43#C42#­N41#O41# pzdo has the inversion center at its centroid, although the O3 sites show half-occupation). Na+ cations form dinuclear moieties acting as the nodes of a 3D pzdo- and octacyano­tungstate(V)-bridged supramolecular architecture. Two kinds of {Na2} dinuclear nodes are distinguished. {Na2-(μ2-O)2} nodes of square-like geometry are formed of two edge-sharing distorted Na+ pseudo-octahedrons with two oxygen O11pzdo atoms acting as the local intranode bridges between two Na1 centers. The coordination sphere of Na1 centers is completed by two nitrogen atoms (N5cyano and N6cyano in cis-configuration) and two oxygen atoms (O34pzdo and O41pzdo in cis-configuration). {Na2-(μ2-O)3} nodes are formed by two face-sharing distorted pseudo-octahedrons with three oxygen atoms O1water, O2water, and O21pzdo acting as the local intranode bridges between Na2 and Na3 centers. This configuration results in distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry (TBPY-5) of {Na2O3} unit with Na atoms at the axial vertices and O bridges at equatorial vertices. The coordination sphere of Na2 cations is completed by two nitrogen atoms, N8cyano and N3cyano, and one oxygen O24pzdo atom. The coordination sphere of Na3 cations is completed by two oxygen atoms, O14pzdo and O31pzdo, and one nitrogen atom, N2cyano. The interatomic distances Na–Opzdo Na–Owater, and Na–Ncyano fall generally within the range of 2.282(3)–2.585(3) Å, with one exceptionally long distance of 2.800(4) Å. These values are in agreement with those of Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O, sodium-crown ethers adducts, as well as for examples of mixed bimetallic sodium-d metal and sodium-f metal ions coordination networks. In 1, these distances reveal a general increasing tendency in order Na+–Opzdo < Na+–NCN < Na+–Owater.

Crystal Structure of 1 

The crystal structure of 1 is presented in Figure  and . The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . The asymmetric unit is composed of 3 Na+ cations, 1 [W(CN)8]3- anion, 3.5 pzdo molecules and 2.5 H2O molecules (the O41N41C42C43C43#C42#N41#O41# pzdo has the inversion center at its centroid, although the O3 sites show half-occupation). Na+ cations form dinuclear moieties acting as the nodes of a 3D pzdo- and octacyanotungstate(V)-bridged supramolecular architecture. Two kinds of {Na2} dinuclear nodes are distinguished. {Na2-(μ2-O)2} nodes of square-like geometry are formed of two edge-sharing distorted Na+ pseudo-octahedrons with two oxygen O11pzdo atoms acting as the local intranode bridges between two Na1 centers. The coordination sphere of Na1 centers is completed by two nitrogen atoms (N5cyano and N6cyano in cis-configuration) and two oxygen atoms (O34pzdo and O41pzdo in cis-configuration). {Na2-(μ2-O)3} nodes are formed by two face-sharing distorted pseudo-octahedrons with three oxygen atoms O1water, O2water, and O21pzdo acting as the local intranode bridges between Na2 and Na3 centers. This configuration results in distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry (TBPY-5) of {Na2O3} unit with Na atoms at the axial vertices and O bridges at equatorial vertices. The coordination sphere of Na2 cations is completed by two nitrogen atoms, N8cyano and N3cyano, and one oxygen O24pzdo atom. The coordination sphere of Na3 cations is completed by two oxygen atoms, O14pzdo and O31pzdo, and one nitrogen atom, N2cyano. The interatomic distances Na-Opzdo Na-Owater, and Na-Ncyano fall generally within the range of 2.282(3)-2.585(3) Å, with one exceptionally long distance of 2.800(4) Å. These values are in agreement with those of Na3[W(CN)8]⋅4H2O, sodium-crown ethers adducts, as well as for examples of mixed bimetallic sodium-d metal and sodium-f metal ions coordination networks. In 1, these distances reveal a general increasing tendency in order Na+-Opzdo < Na+-NCN < Na+-Owater.

elements.content: All pzdo molecules serve as bridging ligands to forms a corrugated 2D Na–O sublattice exhibiting a variety of coordination modes. A simple end-to-end as well as mixed end-on/end-to-end bridging modes are observed. The 3D architecture is additionally stabilized by hydrogen bonding between {Na2O3} and {N2O2} nodes ().
elements.clean_text: All pzdo molecules serve as bridging ligands to forms a corrugated 2D Na-O sublattice exhibiting a variety of coordination modes. A simple end-to-end as well as mixed end-on/end-to-end bridging modes are observed. The 3D architecture is additionally stabilized by hydrogen bonding between {Na2O3} and {N2O2} nodes ().

elements.content: Octacyano­tungstate(V) anions of a geometry very close to SAPR-8 () are surrounded by seven pzdo molecules. The key structural feature in 1 is the alternate stacking arrangement of [W(CN)8]3– and pzdo, where the aromatic rings of the ligand are parallel to the square faces of the [W(CN)8]-square antiprism with the shortest distance of ca. 3.5 Å, which is indicative for anion−π interactions (Figure b, see also the discussion of [W(CN)8] n−–pzdo interactions). Each [W(CN)8]3– moiety forms five cyano-bridges toward neighboring sodium centers of {Na2O3} and {Na2O2} nodes.
elements.clean_text: Octacyanotungstate(V) anions of a geometry very close to SAPR-8 () are surrounded by seven pzdo molecules. The key structural feature in 1 is the alternate stacking arrangement of [W(CN)8]3- and pzdo, where the aromatic rings of the ligand are parallel to the square faces of the [W(CN)8]-square antiprism with the shortest distance of ca. 3.5 Å, which is indicative for anion-π interactions (Figure b, see also the discussion of [W(CN)8] n--pzdo interactions). Each [W(CN)8]3- moiety forms five cyano-bridges toward neighboring sodium centers of {Na2O3} and {Na2O2} nodes.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 is presented in Figure . The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . The asymmetric unit is composed of 2 K+ cations, 1 [W(CN)8]3– anion, 1 pzdo molecule, and 2 H2O molecules. K+ cations are grouped into trinuclear, almost linear moieties acting as the nodes of a unique 1D pzdo- and octacyano­tungstate(V)-bridged belts running along c crystallographic direction, with K2 and W1 atoms lying on a 2-fold axis. These belts are joined by single CN-bridges into 3D supramolecular architecture. {K3-[(μ2-O)2(μ2-N)2]2} nodes are built of three square-face-sharing 8-coordinated moieties. Within the {K3O4N4} the central K2 atom is surrounded by four oxygen atoms, two O1water and two O2water, and four nitrogen atoms, two N1CN and two N3CN, arranged in approximate SAPR-8 geometry. Each group of four atoms (O1, O2, N1, N3) bridges the K2 centers with two side K3 centers. The coordination sphere of K3 centers is completed by the group of three O14pzdo, O11pzdo, N2CN. The interatomic K–Opzdo and K–Owater distances fall generally within the range of 2.689(3)–2.770(3) Å, whereas K–Ncyano distances are in range between 3.024(4) and 3.174(3), with one substantially long distance K3–N4 of 3.391(3) Å. These distances are in agreement with potassium-crown ether adducts as well as with mixed bimetallic potassium-d metal coordination networks.

elements.content: Octacyano­tungstate(V) anions of a distorted SAPR-8 geometry () occupy cavities within the 1D belt architecture. Each [W(CN)8]3– moiety forms six cyanido-bridges toward neighboring potassium centers: four (two C1N1 and two C3N3) within a belt, and two C2N2 between the neighboring belts. All pzdo molecules serve as bridging ligands in two {K-(μ-pzdo)}∞ chains running along the belt and exhibiting one type of end-to-end bridging mode. The appearance of the [K2(μ-pzdo)][W(CN)8] structural motifs along the belt with the diazine aromatic ring oriented parallel to the square face of SAPR-8 (Figure a) similar to 1 (shortest distance of ca. 3.19 Å) suggests the presence of highly directional supramolecular anion−π interactions between the π-acidic pzdo ring and octacyanoungstate anion. Three-dimensional architecture is additionally stabilized by hydrogen bonding between {K 3O4N4} nodes and electrostatic attraction between N+O– groups of parallel pzdo linkers of the neighboring {K 3O4N4} nodes (Figure b).

elements.content: The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . The asymmetric unit is composed of 6 Mn2+ cations, 4 [W(CN)8]3– anions, 4 pzdo molecules and 14 MeOH molecules. 3 reveals a layered coordination structure with original I2O1 inorganic–organic hybrid connectivity. 2D inorganic connectivity is realized through the formation of MnII–NC–WV linkages. The cyanide-bridged skeleton shows mixed square-octagonal grid type topology. The edge sharing 12-membered {Mn2W2(μ-CN)4} rings are ordered in two sets of ladders intersecting obliquely, which results in the formation of 24-membered {Mn4W4(μ-CN)4} rings. 1D organic connectivity is realized through a [Mn-(μ-pzdo)]∞ chains running only along the ladders parallel to b crystallographic direction (2 chains per one ladder). The pzdo bridges Mn centers with O atoms and cap the ladders limiting the growth of 3D coordination skeleton along the c direction. This allow to distinguish triangle-like [Mn2(μ-pzdo)][W(CN)8] coordination motifs with the nearly parallel orientation of pzdo ring plane and square plane of [W(CN)8]3–. The ladders parallel to b directions are corrugated (red color in Figure a,b), while the interconnecting oblique ladders are flat (blue color in Figure a,b). Three-dimensional architecture is stabilized by intralayer hydrogen bonding in Mn–OMeOH···OMeOH···NC–W arrays with O···O distance of ca. 2.55 Å and O···N distance of ca. 2.80 Å. This interaction is effectively supported by electrostatic attraction between N+O– groups of parallel pzdo ligands of neighboring layers.

elements.content: The bond lengths and angles are within the ranges typical for cyanido-bridged Mn–W networks. Two general types of 6-coordinated MnII moieties can be distinguished in coordination skeleton. The first type of MnII units of the general formula fac,cis-[MnII(μ-NC)3(μ-pzdo)2(MeOH)]− is realized at Mn5, Mn7, Mn9, and Mn10 sites, which constitute the CN–-bridged ladders parallel to b direction. The second type of MnII of the general formula mer-[MnII(μ-NC)3(MeOH)3]− forms CN–-bridged connections between these ladders. Two general types of octacyanido­metalate moieties are observed within the ladders parallel to direction b. [W(1)(CN)8] and [W(3)(CN)8] have a geometry close to SAPR-8, each forming four CN–-bridges to four Mn centers, whereas [W(2)(CN)8] and [W(4)(CN)8] have a geometry close to DD-8 (dodecahedron), each forming five CN-bridges to five Mn centers ().

elements.content: The crystal structure of 4 is shown in Figure . The selected bond lengths and angles are presented in . The asymmetric unit is composed of 1 W atom, 5 CN– ligands, 0.5 of Mn2+ atom, 0.5 of pzdo molecules, 2 coordination H2O molecules and 4 crystallization H2O molecules. The extended 3D cyano-bridged coordination framework is built of corrugated 2D tungsten noded Mn2W sheets of square grid topology (Mn–N2–C2–W and Mn–N5–C5–W linkages) joined together by Mn–N4–C4–W linkages (Figure a). This results in the channels occupied by coordination and crystallization H2O molecules and pzdo molecules (Figure b). Interestingly, original motif of W2Mn2 square-based V-shaped ladder appear as a CN-bridged substructure along b direction (Figure c). The 3D architecture is controlled by local hydrogen bonding with Owater···Owater distances of ca. 2.55 Å and Owater···NC–W distance of ca. 2.94 Å.

elements.content: Manganese centers coordinate three nitrogen atoms [W(CN)8]4– units in mer-geometry. The pseudo-octahedral coordination is completed by two oxygen atoms of H2O molecules and one oxygen end of pzdo ligand. The pzdo molecules are involved in the formation of local organic dinuclear coordination arrangement [MnII 2-(μ-pzdo)], giving pzdo-capped perpendicularly oriented [MnII 2-(μ-pzdo)]{(μ-CN)2-[WIV(CN)6]}2 squares (Figure d). The bridging coordination of pzdo is realized by the ideal cis conformation with the torsion angle Mn–O–O′–Mn′ 0°. The basal plane of pzdo ligands is oriented almost parallel to the plane of Mn2Nb2 square. Octacyano­tungstate moieties of square-antiprismatic geometry (SAPR) slightly distorted toward bicapped trigonal prism (BTP) coordinate six neighboring manganese centers (), giving rise to W/Mn 6:3 inorganic connectivity. The compound 4 is structurally closely related to its [Nb(CN)8]4–-based analogue {MnII 2(pzdo)(H2O)4[NbIV(CN)8]}·4H2O (5), as both compounds reveal similar composition, I3O0 hybrid connectivity and mer-[MnII(μ-NC)3(H2O)(μ-pzdo)] coordination moieties. However, these compounds crystallize in different space groups and reveal significant difference in the local coordination arrangement of pzdo. In 4, the pzdo tends to cap W2Mn2 squares with the ideal (by symmetry) cis bridging mode Mn–O–O′Mn′, whereas in 5, it caps NbMn2 trinuclear unit with the almost ideal gauche mode with Mn–O–O′–Mn′ angle of 91.7°. The difference between the crystal structures of 4 and 5 could be assigned to the differences in the standard Nb–C (2.2–2.3 Å) and W–C (2.1–2.2 Å) distances. Similarly to 1–3, pzdo in 4 is involved in particular interactions with the cyanide ligands of the [W(CN)8]-moiety: end-to-face interactions with the shortest distance of 3.28 Å and edge-to-face interactions with the shortest distances of 3.16–3.19 Å.

elements.content: Coordination motifs and supramolecular interactions in 1–5. The crystal structures of 1–5 compounds are built of [M′(CN)8] n− (M′ = WV, WIV, NbIV) anions and pzdo molecules, with different incorporated metal ions M (M = Na+, K+, Mn2+). This results in the presence of recognizable pzdo-based coordination motifs: pzdo- and cyano-bridged [Na2(μ-pzdo)Na][W(CN)8] triangles (1), [M(μ-pzdo)M][M′(CN)8] triangles (2, 3, and 5) or [M(μ-pzdo)M][M′(CN)8]2 squares (4) (Figure ). The [M′(CN)8]-pzdo supramolecular interactions (Figure ) can be divided into several general groups: (a) face-to-face sandwich type interactions with the plane of pyrazine ring generally parallel to the ideal or average N4 square faces of [M′(CN)8] n− anions (see Figure a–c, e), (b) double edge-to-face [M′(CN)8]–pzdo interactions with two neighboring CN– groups tending toward the atoms of the pyrazine ring (present in 4, see Figure d), and (c) single end-to-face (present in 4) or bent sandwich end-to-face (present in 1, see Figure a), with CN– groups pointing toward the centroids of pzdo ring. This interactions accompany the cyclic coordination [M(μ-pzdo)M][M′(CN)8] x motifs. They are characterized by molecular arrangements and Npzdo···NCN or Cpzdo···NCN distances in the range of 3.0–3.8 Å, respectively. Moreover, the pzdo–pzdo interactions through dipolar electrostatic interactions between N–δO+δ groups in 2 and 3 lead to the alternate almost parallel face-to-face arrangement of pzdo in the neighboring layers with the distance between pyrazine rings of ca. 3–3.2 Å (see Figure b and Figure c).

elements.content: Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O and K3[W(CN)8 ]·1.5H2O salts in solid state are orange and yellow, respectively, and their aqueous solutions in water are colorless. Contrary to that, the crystals of 1 and 2 have intense brown color and their aqueous solutions reveal well recognizable pale brown tint. The solid state and aqueous solution electronic spectra of 1 and 2 are presented in Figure . Solid state spectra of 1 and 2 exhibit very strong absorption in the 200–400 nm range, which is accompanied by relatively weaker broad band in the visible region of 400–750 nm. Considering the spectra of pzdo, Na3[W(CN)8 ]·4H2O and K3[W(CN)8 ]·1.5H2O, the UV absorption in 1 and 2 can be assigned to the sum of (i) intraligand (IL) transitions of pzdo and (ii) ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions from CN– to WV within the [WV(CN)8]3– moieties, including also some admixture of ligand field (LF) transitions. The absorption above 400 nm correlates with the presence of the intermolecular interactions between [W(CN)8]3– anions and other species present in the solid state: H2O and alkali metal cations through numerous W–CN···H–OH, W–CN···M + interactions frozen in solid state. In the result, the presence of alkali metal cations extends the absorption up to 600 nm (Na+ salt) or 530 nm (K+ salt). The incorporation of pzdo results in the appearance of a new absorption bands centered at 570 nm (1) or 510 nm (2) extending the absorption range up to 700 nm (1) or 750 nm (2). The presence of this band in the visible spectra of 1 and 2 can be understood in terms of the specific interaction between the diazine aromatic ring of pzdo and cyanide ligands of the [W(CN)8] n− anion, probably of charge transfer (CT) nature. It is worth noting that neither the white solid of TBA3[W(CN)8] nor the colorless aqueous solutions of simple Na+ and K+ salts of [W(CN)8]3– show any absorption in visible range, due to the absence of any intermolecular interactions indicated above. More interestingly, 1 and 2 dissolved in water reveal also moderately strong absorption in range 400–600 nm (Figure , the insets). This clearly suggests that pzdo and [WCN)8]3– interactions exist in the solution.

elements.content:
Compounds 1 and 2 are paramagnetic down to 2 K due to the presence of isolated paramagnetic [WV(CN)8]3– complexes (see Figures S2 and S3 for details).

The magnetic properties of 3 are determined by WV and MnII spins coupled by an exchange interaction through CN bridges within the layers and a much weaker magnetic interaction between the layers. The susceptibility χ(T) was measured using the field of 1 kOe in the temperature range from 300 to 2 K. It is shown as 1/χ(T) in Figure , and as χT(T) in . Fitting of the 1/χ(T) = (T – θCW)/C equation (the Curie–Weiss model) to the inverse susceptibility in the range from 200 to 300 K leads to the Curie constant C = 26.1(5) cm3·K·mol–1 and the Weiss temperature θCW = −16(2) K. This C value is close to 27.7 cm3·K·mol–1 calculated for uncoupled six MnII centers (S Mn = 5/2, g Mn = 2.0) and four WV centers (S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0). The negative θCW value points to predominantly antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between Mn and W centers. This is also visible in χT(T) dependence as a shallow minimum around 200 K. In the crystal structure of 3, there are 6 inequivalent positions of Mn and 4 inequivalent positions of W leading to 18 different CN bridges and different exchange constants. For this reason, the use of a mean-field model including all these exchange constants would lead during the fitting procedure to an overparametrization of available data, and therefore, only the simple Curie–Weiss model was used. The value θCW obtained from the highest temperature range is an average of all magnetic interactions present in the system.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Compounds 1 and 2 are paramagnetic down to 2 K due to the presence of isolated paramagnetic [WV(CN)8]3- complexes (see  Figures S2 and S3 for details).

The magnetic properties of 3 are determined by WV and MnII spins coupled by an exchange interaction through CN bridges within the layers and a much weaker magnetic interaction between the layers. The susceptibility χ(T) was measured using the field of 1 kOe in the temperature range from 300 to 2 K. It is shown as 1/χ(T) in Figure , and as χT(T) in . Fitting of the 1/χ(T) = (T - θCW)/C equation (the Curie-Weiss model) to the inverse susceptibility in the range from 200 to 300 K leads to the Curie constant C = 26.1(5) cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 and the Weiss temperature θCW = -16(2) K. This C value is close to 27.7 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 calculated for uncoupled six MnII centers (S Mn = 5/2, g Mn = 2.0) and four WV centers (S W = 1/2, g W = 2.0). The negative θCW value points to predominantly antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between Mn and W centers. This is also visible in χT(T) dependence as a shallow minimum around 200 K. In the crystal structure of 3, there are 6 inequivalent positions of Mn and 4 inequivalent positions of W leading to 18 different CN bridges and different exchange constants. For this reason, the use of a mean-field model including all these exchange constants would lead during the fitting procedure to an overparametrization of available data, and therefore, only the simple Curie-Weiss model was used. The value θCW obtained from the highest temperature range is an average of all magnetic interactions present in the system.

elements.content: The magnetic exchange constant for Mn–NC–W is negative for all reported polynuclear MnW cyanide-bridged assemblies. With the negative exchange constants for all Mn–W neighbors within single layer of 3, the anticipated antiparallel arrangement of Mn and W magnetic moments lead to a ferrimagnetic structure of the single layer in a ground state. This is visible as an increasing χT(T) below 100 K reaching elevated values above 900 cm3·K·mol–1 (see ).
elements.clean_text: The magnetic exchange constant for Mn-NC-W is negative for all reported polynuclear MnW cyanide-bridged assemblies. With the negative exchange constants for all Mn-W neighbors within single layer of 3, the anticipated antiparallel arrangement of Mn and W magnetic moments lead to a ferrimagnetic structure of the single layer in a ground state. This is visible as an increasing χT(T) below 100 K reaching elevated values above 900 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (see ).

elements.content: To search for a magnetic ordering transition zero-field cooled and field-cooled (ZFC/FC) magnetization measurement was performed using a low field of 15 Oe. Both ZFC and FC curves (inset in Figure ) reveals at T c = 17.5 K a peak, characteristic for a long-range antiferromagnetic ordering. A small difference between ZFC and FC curves below T c points to a small irreversibility of magnetic behavior of 3 below T c.. This led us to perform ac susceptibility measurements using different driving field frequencies (see ). The position of the χ′ susceptibility peak does not depend on the frequency which excludes a spin-glass behavior. Also the χ’’ signal is very small, χ’’/χ′ is below 0.005 at the χ’’ maximum. Such behavior is in agreement with the long-range antiferromagnetic order below T c in 3.
elements.clean_text: To search for a magnetic ordering transition zero-field cooled and field-cooled (ZFC/FC) magnetization measurement was performed using a low field of 15 Oe. Both ZFC and FC curves (inset in Figure ) reveals at T c = 17.5 K a peak, characteristic for a long-range antiferromagnetic ordering. A small difference between ZFC and FC curves below T c points to a small irreversibility of magnetic behavior of 3 below T c.. This led us to perform ac susceptibility measurements using different driving field frequencies (see ). The position of the χ' susceptibility peak does not depend on the frequency which excludes a spin-glass behavior. Also the χ'' signal is very small, χ''/χ' is below 0.005 at the χ'' maximum. Such behavior is in agreement with the long-range antiferromagnetic order below T c in 3.

elements.content: Below T c the measured susceptibility of 3 depends of the applied field, which is shown in Figure . At 0.5 kOe, the χ(T) maximum around 17.0 K is sharp. At the field of 1 kOe the maximum flattens and moves to about 13 K, and eventually, at the field of 2 kOe, the maximum disappears completely. Such dependence is typical for an antiferromagnetic structure, in which applied magnetic field overcomes an antiferromagnetic interaction and eventually aligns the magnetic moments parallel. The magnetization curve measured at 2 K (Figure ) has an inflection point at H c = 1050 Oe, which has the same origin as above-described χ(T) behavior. With the increase of temperature the M(H) dependencies show a systematic shift of H c toward lower values of H, with H c disappearing close to T c (Figure inset A). The energy βH c at 2 K corresponds to temperature 0.06 K, much smaller than the ordering temperature T c, and the θCW temperature. Therefore, the transition at H c is related to overcoming of interlayer antiferromagnetic interaction by applied field, whereas the ferrimagnetic arrangement between Mn and W within layers are left intact by such a small field. This estimation is confirmed by the magnetization curve at high fields. At 50 kOe the magnetization saturates at the value 25.1(5) Nβ, just below 26 Nβ expected for MnII 6WV 4 formula unit with antiparallel magnetic moments of Mn and W. Summarizing the magnetic structure of 3, there is the ferrimagnetic order within the layers due to AF exchange interaction between Mn and W, and the layers are antiferromagnetically ordered due to the AF interaction between layers. The M(H) data measured in T range of 2–18 K were used for the construction of a magnetic phase diagram showing the transition between antiferromagnetic and paramagnetic phases (Figure , inset B). The critical points at were taken as the maxima of dM/dH(H) dependencies at fixed temperatures ().

elements.content: Combination of the π-acidic pzdo molecule with electron-rich octacyanometalate anions leads to a systematic formation of pzdo-capped [M(μ-pzdo)M][W(CN)8] or [M(μ-pzdo)M][W(CN)8]2 coordination motifs in the resulting extended networks 1–4. In particular, we have distinguished and described the supramolecular interations between [W(CN)8] and pzdo of the face-to-face, edge-to-face, and end-to-face type. The electronic interactions between pzdo and [W(CN)8] within the reported systems are manifested by the visible light absorption bands of the solid state as well as of aqueous solutions of 1 and 2, probably CT in nature. Our observations are in accordance with predictable electron deficiency on π-orbital cloud due to O atoms bound to N atoms of pyrazine ring. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report recognizing and describing the anion−π interactions in octacyanometalate-based coordination networks. Magnetic studies revealed that 1, 2, and 4 are paramagnetic, whereas 3 orders antiferromagnetically at T c = 17.5 K due to the exchange Mn–NC–W interaction within layers and weaker interlayer magnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Combination of the π-acidic pzdo molecule with electron-rich octacyanometalate anions leads to a systematic formation of pzdo-capped [M(μ-pzdo)M][W(CN)8] or [M(μ-pzdo)M][W(CN)8]2 coordination motifs in the resulting extended networks 1-4. In particular, we have distinguished and described the supramolecular interations between [W(CN)8] and pzdo of the face-to-face, edge-to-face, and end-to-face type. The electronic interactions between pzdo and [W(CN)8] within the reported systems are manifested by the visible light absorption bands of the solid state as well as of aqueous solutions of 1 and 2, probably CT in nature. Our observations are in accordance with predictable electron deficiency on π-orbital cloud due to O atoms bound to N atoms of pyrazine ring. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report recognizing and describing the anion-π interactions in octacyanometalate-based coordination networks. Magnetic studies revealed that 1, 2, and 4 are paramagnetic, whereas 3 orders antiferromagnetically at T c = 17.5 K due to the exchange Mn-NC-W interaction within layers and weaker interlayer magnetic interactions.

elements.content: Our study provides new perspectives in the design of cyanide-bridged molecular solids, new means for the control of their supramolecular architectures and allows for tuning of their optical properties.
elements.clean_text: Our study provides new perspectives in the design of cyanide-bridged molecular solids, new means for the control of their supramolecular architectures and allows for tuning of their optical properties.

{Mn<sub>6</sub>(pzdo)<sub>4</sub>(MeOH)<sub>10</sub>[W(CN)<sub>8</sub>]<sub>4</sub>}·4MeOH (<bold>3</bold>)

A MeOH suspension of pzdo (0.27 mmol, 0.0302 g, 10 mL) was mixed with MeOH solution containing MnCl2·4H2O (0.054 mmol, 0.0107 g, 10 mL) and Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O (0.036 mmol, 0.0192 g). The mixture was tightly closed in a conical flask and kept in water bath at 40 °C. After 1 week, the flask was slightly unsealed, which allowed a slow exchange of solvent vapors. After 2 days, elongated, needle-shaped, brown crystals of 3 appeared. The crystals together with a small portion of mother solution were separated mechanically from the pzdo suspension and characterized by monocrystalline X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurement. The fast degradation of crystallinity of 3 was observed after their removal from the mother liquor due to the exchange of MeOH to H2O. This yield in the dark brown material of empirical formula {Mn6(pzdo)4[W(CN)8]4}·3MeOH·8H2O (see elemental analysis below). Yield: 4 mg ca. 8%. Anal. Calcd for C51H44Mn6N40O19W4: C, 23.6; H, 2.0; N, 21.6. Found: C, 23.8; H, 2.2; N, 21.6. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3478v, 3363, 3216, 3023, 2916, 2847, 2174m, 2150m, 2132w, 1623m, 1602s, 1477s, 1451s, 1314m, 1251m, 1236m, 1184vw, 1082w, 1053s, 878m, 848m, 811vs, 600w, 466m.

{Mn<sup>II</sup> <sub>2</sub>(pzdo)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>[W<sup>IV</sup>(CN)<sub>8</sub>]}·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Aqueous solutions of MnCl2·4H2O (0.5 mmol, 99 mg, 1 mL) and pzdo (5 mmol, 112 mg, 5 mL) were mixed, and then an aqueous solution of Na3[W(CN)8]·4H2O (0.5 mmol, 266 mg, 5 mL) was added. The resulting red solution was filtered. After a few days, thin orange needles were obtained, separated by filtration, and removed. The supernatant was left in the dark. After 3 weeks, red prismatic single crystals suitable for structure determination were obtained. Yield: 15.2 mg, ca. 8%. Anal. Calcd for C12H20Mn2N10O10W: C, 19.0; H, 2.7; N, 18.5.
